column9:
755320: Load the relevant packages, the Election Campaign 2022 dataset and the Election Campaign codebook.
In this quiz we will explore how a usual suspect sociodemographic variable, age, is related to political attitudes.
As our dependent variable / response variable, the quiz will use four different survey questions capturing political attitudes.
The names of the four response variables are:

Extra_FaithInPublicHospitalSystem
Extra_CompensateInflation
Extra_ImmigrationIsAThreat
Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough

The labels are somewhat indicative of what the response variables capture. But it is always a good idea to use the codebook to understand the survey questions and scaling properly! I have been to one too many presentations, where the "direction" of the regression coefficient was misunderstood since the scaling of the regressor or response variable was misinterpreted.
Use the codebook to answer: What does a value of "4" mean on the Extra_CompensateInflation variable?
column11: 758319: On a scale from 0 (the worst possible quiz for this course) to 10 (the best possible quiz for this course), how would you rate the quiz, that you have just completed?
column13:
758320: If you have any suggestions as to how we can improve these quizzes, feel free to let us know here.
If you don't have any suggestions, just type a blank space
column15:
755321: Before running a regression analysis it is always important to get a sense of the data we are analysing.
For example, by running a histogram on the age variable we see two respondents are much older than 100 years. This is highly unlikely, so we will filter out these respondents.
Use the same code to inspect the variable Extra_FaithInPublicHospitalSystemin a histogram with a binwidth of 1.
Which of the two statements describes the distribution better?
column17:
755325: Now that we know the variables, we can run a correlation analysis!
Find the correlation coefficient between age and Extra_FaithInPublicHospitalSystem.
For the cor function to work, we must first inspect if there are any NAs on the attitude variable. If there are, please remove these and then run the analysis.
What is the correlation coefficient? (write your answer with three digits)

column21:
755333: No matter which attitude variable you investigated before, the coefficient would be significant. Does this mean we are ready to publish our first paper?
Not exactly. A good rule of thumb is that if you cannot visualize a result, it is not substantially important, even though it might be statistically significant. This is because with a large enough N, and enough statistical power, even the smallest statistical relationships can be statistically significant.
Therefore you should now visualize the relationship between age and faith in the Public Hospital Systemin a jittered scatter plot.
Do you think the relationship between the two variables is substantially important? Describe the relationship between the two variables and give your verdict!

Yet, run them such that the strength of the coefficients is comparable. This means that we have to rescale the variables and make sure that the two models are run with the same observations, if one or both the regressor variables have missingness.

column43:
By visualizing the relationship between age and the idea that the unemployed don't do enough in a plot, we see that the regression line is almost horizontal. This plot suggests that age doesn't really influence the idea that the unemployed don't do enough ; therefore the relationship between the two variables doesn't seem substantially important. 

We can also see that the points on the plot don't form a particular pattern.

Even if as age increases, the idea that the unemployed don't do enough tends to slightly decrease, the relationship between those two variables seems negligible, because the correlation is close to zero.

column51:
Starting from the age of 20, people are less likely to think that immigration is a threat (point is more than 2.5 but below 3). When age goes up, people relatively turn to agree more with this idea, in which the line reaches 3.5 at the age of 90. 

Since there is no significant change in the graph, or there is only a minor change in the score of immigrationisathreat between the age of 20 and 90, the relationship between the two variables is not substantially important.

column21:
The graph shows a steady increase of the Faith in the Public Hospital System with increasing age.

The correcation line starts at the age of about 20 with the Faith at the value 3.5. This increases to about the value of 4 at the age of 80.

Given the steadiness of the increase, I would say that the relationship between these two variables are important. However the increase is only about 0.5 points in 60 years, so the strength of the increas is not very strong. So the relationship between age and Faith in the Public Hospital System should not be substantially important.

column29:
There is a slight negative correlation between age and the idea that citizens should be compensated for inflation.

From the visual reprensentation of the relationship, it is shown that the distribution of people older than 40 are slightly more dense than ages below, the more they agree with the idea that they should be compensated (values 3-5). However, there is also a slight increase in ages below 40, in the value of 4 meaning that a substiantially amount of people younger than 40 also somewhat agree that they should be compensated. However, the linear regression shows that the relationship between age and the attitude variable, is negative; meaning that however small, the plot shows that the younger you are the more you believe you should be compensated. However, my verdict is that there is an overall equal distribution between all ages, and that they all somewhat agree.

column29:
The slope describing the best linear model for the relationship between the predictor variable 'age' and the outcome variable 'Extra_CompensateInflation' is -0,002. This indicate that when a person turn one year older, they become 0,002 less supportive in the idea that the citizens should be compensated for inflation. It is a very insignificant change in the opinions even after 60years (adds up to decline in the support for the idea with 0,12 - on the scale from 1-5), even though the relationship is significant on a 5% significant level. 

When standardising the variables, the slope for the standardised age is -0,024. This indicates that when age change with 1 standard deviation, the supportiveness of the compensation idea is predicted to decline with 0,024 standard deviation. This also indicates a small impact the age variable has on the respondents supportiveness for the idea of inflation compensation. 

The relationship between the 2 variables does not have substantially importance.
